tei:encodingDesc.tei:p: Facsimile encoding includes selections of the source text highlighted by the annotator. Each selected area of a page is encoded as a zone placed at the end of the page's surface element. Each selected segment of text is contained by anchor elements.

Annotations are stored in the text using the note element with a target attribute that references the corresponding selection in the facsimile. Annotation content is contained by p elements and separately as raw Markdown in a code element.
Citations made in the annotations are stored in a listBibl at the end of the text.

EMORY UNIVERSITY
LIBRARY
Will
Presentation
In presenting this, the initial volume of the
Asodecoan, we hope that it may meet with your
approval. We, the untalented editors, have en¬
countered many difficulties, but have endeavored
to portray for you our college life as we saw it.
In our future years we trust that it shall be the
means of drawing us closer together into the
bonds of fellowship, as it recalls again to our
memories our fellow classmates, the beloved mem¬
bers of our faculty, and our dear institution. If
such shall be the case, we will feel that all our
work has not been in vain.
Now, kind reader, we ask that you do not crit¬
icise us too harshly during your perusal of these
pages, but treat kindly with us for the numerous
errors that have been made, remembering that
this is our first attempt to pose as
Editors.

The Atlanta-Southern Dental College
MIE Atlanta-Southern Dental College is a combination of words which, to
the casual observer, means but little, but to the dental profession and peo¬
ple of the South, the full understanding of its true meaning brings a thrill
of gratification and a deep sense of satisfaction. To the dental profession, be¬
cause a combination of the two leading institutions for the teaching of dentistry
in the South, means that petty jealousies, rivalry and competition are eliminated
and that the ambition for a college that could more nearly realize the "ideal" is
made possible.
With the faculty of the two former colleges, the dental and medical profession
of Atlanta, to draw from, a combination of teachers is available which may easily
be classed among the peers of faculties for professional schools.
The equipment selected from the two former colleges has been supplemented
in the various departments and an entirely new department of laboratory physi¬
ology has been opened which is but one of the various features which are to be
added each year in an effort to keep abreast the wonderful progress being achieved
in the dental science.
The joining of hands of the alumni of the two former institutions will have
its effect over the entire South, as it will harmonize their efforts in their various
localities for the uplift of their chosen profession.
To the people of the South it means a better educated dentist, both from the
literary and professional standpoint, to serve them.
It makes possible higher preliminary educational requirements for entrance,
a more thoroughly trained and more competent dentist being graduated.
Appreciating as they do the value of dental surgery and the meaning in con¬
nection with health and longevity, much is to be gained by this combination, and
hearty approval is being daily voiced.
We, the Class of 1918, feel that we are to be congratulated as being the first
to receive diplomas from this institution, and express our appreciation by say¬
ing that the value of the combination of Atlanta-Southern Dental College is kindly
appreciated, thoroughly approved and heartily endorsed, and bind ourselves uncon¬
ditionally to work hereafter for success so much deserved.

HUNTEB SPICEB ALLEN
Selma, Ala.
We now gaze upon the original comedian from
Alabama. He received his early education in the graded
and high schools of Selma. Hunter came to us in the
Fall of '15 and during his three years here has been
one of the best liked fellows in the class. Hunter has
the honor of being a fellow who can make friends with
everybody. We feel safe in predicting for him a great
and glorious future.
Cartoonist for 1918 Annual
GERALD F. ALTEE
E W $
Jacksonville, Fla.
He received his preliminary education in the public
schools of Columbia, S. C. After finishing at Winona
Tech, Indianapolis, Ind., he later moved from Colum¬
bia to Jacksonville, Fla., where he was employed in
the mechanical department of the S. A. L. R. R. until he
decided upon a professional career. He entered the S.
D. C. in '15.
VINCENT JAMES ALTEE
E W $
Jacksonville, Fla.
He received his preliminary education in the high
schools of Jacksonville. After finishing high school he
was connected with one of the '' movie'' companies
which winter in Jacksonville, and also did clerical work
in several other lines of business. Deciding to do his
part toward relieving suffering humanity he entered
the S. D. C. in '15. Since he has been in College he has
been a quiet and studious worker. We think that from
his record he will be a success in his chosen profession.
Member Annual Staff 1918

ARY EUGENE D'ARMONA
2 * E, 0 N E, $ B n, B $ K.
Key West, Fla.
'' Swifty, De Ammonia, NH.„ Army''—for his nick¬
names are legion—entered our midst after various col¬
legiate affiliations. He was upon his career of medicine
at the University of Virginia, but decided to acquire a
degree of D.D.S. and become a famous oral surgeon.
Some day we expect to hear great things of him.
STEPHENS LANHAN BALDWIN
¥ Q
Atlanta, Ga.
"Steve" graduated at Tech High in 1913 and after
one year at Georgia Teeh could not resist his profes¬
sional calling. In '15 he enrolled at the S. D. C. His
College life has been such that in later years he can
look back upon it as one of the brightest spots in his
career. Being naturally gifted in the profession which
he has chosen and endowed with those social qualifica¬
tions which make friends wherever he goes, fame is al¬
ready knocking at his door.
GORDON KIMBALL BARKLEY
E W $
Bristol, Tenn.
Barkley, after a rather varied career, which included
"doing his bit" for Uncle Sam as an electrician and
radio operator in the navy, decided that the road to
success and fame was best traveled by one bearing the
degree of D.D.S. His success in College may be shown
as marked in view of the position he holds.
President Class 1917-'18.

HENRY ARTHUR BENTON
Knoxville, Tenn.
Entered the Atlanta Dental College in 1915, which
later became Atlanta-Southern Dental College. Benton,
by his '' stickability'' and earnest efforts has won among
his fellow students, many friends. He is better known
to be one of the men who always sticks closely to his
duties. He is also one of the leaders of his class, both
from a theoretical and mechanical standpoint. We pre¬
dict for Henry a future success.
PHILIP C. BLOUNT
^ Q
Doyline, La.
Blount never has much to say, and here is a good
evidence of the desirability of silence as a manly attri¬
bute. For the word '' failure'' is not in his vocabulary.
His opinions are always worthy of an audience. He
is a bear for work and always has the air of a man who
has a definite aim in view, and a firm determination to
attain it. A modest supposition is that in his case ap¬
pearances are not deceitful.
CHARLES ROBERTSON BRICE
¥ Q
Gainesville, Ga.
Charles received his early education in the graded
and high schools of Gainesville. At first, trying the dry
goods business and soon tiring of same, Brice decided
to try his hand at dentistry. He has been a diligent
worker and has accomplished much in his course at Col¬
lege. Brice has been always ready to help a classmate
and has made many friends during his stay with us. We
feel safe in prophesying a great future for him.
Vice-President
Annual 1918.
Class 1915-'16; Assistant Editor of

('HAS. H. BRYAN
E V *
Apex, N. C.
" Chas." received his elementary education at Merry
Oaks High School. The farm held no charm for him.
He entered the Atlanta Dental College in 1915 and has
made himself very proficient in operative work and ranks
among the best of his class in theory. Many friends
predict for him a successful future, ami judging from
his ability as an operator he will soon become one of the
leaders of his profession.
HAROLD CRAWFORD BUGG
Madison, Ga.
Harold received his preliminary education from the
Madison High School; entered the A. D. C. in 1915;
was drafted into the National Army in 1917; being
released, after enlisting in the medical reserve. By his
good nature and hard work he has made many friends,
and we predict a great success for him wherever his
duty may call.
ERNEST HERMAN BURGER
Atlanta, Ga.
This handsome young man received his high school
education at Boys High and Tech High. Graduating
from the latter he entered the S. D. C. in '15. For
the last two years he has been associated with the Yarn
Dental Laboratory. His summers and spare time have
been put to good advantage and he has acquired con¬
siderable skill in this line of work. During his stay
with us he has made a good student and a close ob¬
server, therefore we can predict none but a grand suc¬
cess for him.

CARL LEON BUSBEE
Wagoner, S. C.
Comes boasting of the grand old State of South
Carolina. He received his literary education at Wag¬
oner High Schools. At the early age of 18 his desire
was to enter the professional world, entering the South¬
ern Dental College with the Class of '15. His time
has been well spent; what Ben does, he does well. His
friends are many; his record shows him to be among
the best of his class. We predict for him a success
which will surely come.
JOSEPH ALEXANDER BUSSELL
Mystic, Ga.
It is with pleasure that we introduce this gentleman,
a son of South Georgia. Bussell received his early edu¬
cation at Mercer University. After leaving school he
followed several lines of work, among which were mer¬
cantile and farming, but being dissatisfied with these
he entered our College in the year of '15. Bussell is
one of the most ardent and studious workers of the
Senior Class, and with these qualities has attained a
high record as a student. We predict for him only
the best.
Associate Editor Annual 1918~; Class Poet 1916-'17.
GEORGE SIDNEY CALLAHAN
¥ Q
Woodville, Ga.
Callahan is a man of few words, but what he says
always counts. He goes about his work with a silent
vim which has and will reward him with complete suc¬
cess. He came to us from the Woodville High School
after having graduated from that aged institution. We
send him forth with the best wishes for the future, be¬
lieving that he will put into practice the work, enthu¬
siasm and application that he has incorporated in his
college course.

A9i
He attended high school at Hickory; also spent
two years at Lenoir College. While there he decided
to study Dentistry and entered the A. D. C. in '15.
"Jimmie" has always made a good record in College,
notwithstanding the fact that he is a " ladies' man''.
We predict for him a bright future.
SAMUEL TILLMAN CARR
Rocky Face, Ga.
Sam began his career in life as instructor in high
school. He became dissatisfied with the good which
could be accomplished in this phase of life. Realizing
that he could be of greater service to mankind in a
professional capacity he chose Dentistry as his lot.
Carr entered the Loyola University in '15, spent one
year, and came to us in the Fall of '16. We all feel
proud of and wish to recommend him to the public as
one of the most conscientious and practical men who
will leave our College. We feel sure that success will
crown his life.
HENRY W. CATRON
S W $
Kyles Ford, Tenn.
He comes from the beautiful valley of East Ten¬
nessee. Received his early education in the high schools
of Hancock County, his College education at Carson—
Newman College. He decided he could be of great ser¬
vice to suffering humanity by allaying pain, and en¬
tered the S. D. C. in '15. He is a man of many vir¬
tues. His high ideals of manhood have won for him a
[dace in the hearts of each and everyone in College.
President class 1916-'17; Class Poet 1917- '18.

HUDDIE LEE CHENEY
¥ Q
Shellman, Ga.
Cheney came to us in '15 from Shellman, Ga., af¬
ter being graduated from the High Schools of that
place. He has the very admirable trait of speaking
when speech is necessary and remaining quiet at the
proper time. His work has always shown the care and
thought of the maker, and his theoretical knowledge
goes without question. He has been one of the most
regular attendants on lectures throughout his entire Col¬
lege course and his notes make an accurate guide to the
lectures on any date. We know that his will be a large
and remunerative practice as well as a great benefit to
the people with whom he comes in contact.
ARTHUR HAMPTON COKER
Brewton, Ala.
Arthur came to us from Alabama. He received his
early training there in the graded and high school. In
the Fall of '15 Arthur heard the call of Dentistry and
quickly responded. Being one of the hardest workers
in the class, he has accomplished many things during his
stay with us, and has made many steadfast friends
among the boys, who will always remember him as a
good friend. With his increasing knowledge we predict
for this fellow a successful career.
PRESTON BROOKS CONNER, Jr.
¥ Q
Greenwood, S. C.
When the boys of '15 met Brooks for the first time,
they met one of the most conscientious fellows they had
ever known. Brooks received his early education in the
graded and high school of Greenwood and the Bailey
Military Institute. Soon tiring of military life Brooks
left school and tried his hand at mechanics in which he
succeeded, but after staying in his father's office for a
while he soon realized that he was to follow in his
father's footsteps. He is possessed with a good dispo¬
sition and has made numberless friends while at Col¬
lege. We predict for this young man a promising
future.
Class Poet 1916-'17.
"A ray of sunshine from Virginia." To know him
is to like him, for he is a man, gentle as a dentist,
conscientious as a friend, the same yesterday, today ami
tomorrow. Crank speaks with that typical accent of
the Virginians, which fact made him the center of much
curiosity when he first entered the A. D. C. Appar¬
ently he has overcome most of that '' defect,'' and
therefore, we now rest assured of his success, that be¬
ing the only fault we could find in him.
Class Historian 1916-'17.
WILLIAM CLYDE CURRENT
V Q
Statesville, N. C.
In introducing another from the '' Tar Heel'' State,
we wish to say that he seems to be blessed with more
good looks and good judgment than most of them.
Current after completing his literary course decided
that his services to humanity should be through the
medium of Dentistry. Since then he has shown by his
constant application that he realizes the many respon¬
sibilities of his future professional career. We are con¬
fident that the world will know more of him in the
future.
SAMUEL H. DICKEY
V Q
Wellington, Ala.
'' Dick,'' a very pleasant and popular son of Wel¬
lington, Ala. Received his preliminary education at
Jacksonville State Normal. It is a far better pleasure
to know him than to '' read about'' him, his many
friends of both sex will tell you. He has been a very
essential part of the clinic anil laboratory where all of
his work has met with high success.
Wa
Doub, like many other members of the class, hails
from the old North State. Graduated from Whitsett
Institute in '14, he entered A. D. C. in the Fall of
the same year, but unfortunately on account of sick¬
ness, was compelled to suspend his studies in the middle
of his Senior year. We were glad to have him with us
in the Fall of '17 and predict for him success, as he is
equipped with all the essentials which competent and
efficient service demands.
CHARLES LEWIS DOUGLAS
¥ Q
Atlanta, Ga.
One more genteel and amicable than Lewis is not to
be found. He received his high school training at
Brewton, Ala. Having a keen vision of the opportu¬
nity before him he entered Tech High of this city;
after three years' training there he, feeling a higher
and nobler calling, entered the S. D. C. in '15 and here
he has proven himself capable and willing to get all
that is afforded him in College. The door of success is
open to him. He is ready and we all feel sure that he
will make good.
LEWIS JUSTICE DUPREE
Angier, N. C.
He entered high school at Angier where he mastered
the necessary degree to enter the A. D. C. Dr. Dupree,
better known as '' Dupe'' among his class-mates, is so
deeply interested in the subject of Dentistry that his
whole ambition is to remain in his room and burn the
midnight oil in order that he may secure a place at the
top of his profession. We are glad to say that there
isn 't any reason why he should not succeed.

SAM MANSON EASLEY
Tunnel Hill, Ga.
Here we present one of the most jovial and biggest
hearted members of the Senior Class. Sam received his
early education at Reinhardt College. He came to the
S. D. C. in '15. Sam has had a good word for every¬
one of his class-mates and has conducted himself in
such a way that he has won the respect and admira¬
tion of every member of his class. We can sincerely
recommend him to the people in the community which
he locates as being a most true and generous man.
GRADY WOOD EASON
Daviston, Ala.
It is with great pleasure that we invite your atten¬
tion to the young Alabamian, who has acquired so many
friends in the A. S. D. C. through his ever willingness
to lend a helping hand. Most of his time and energy
is spent in diligently acquiring the worthy necessity
of his profession. He received his preliminary educa¬
tion in the Columbus High School. He entered the
S. D. C. in the Fall of '15. We predict for him a
success.
ALFRED CULVER EDWARDS
V Q
Laundale, N. C.
A. C, at the age of 17, entered Piedmont High
School and graduated from that institution three years
hence. Believing that success only comes to the man
who does one thing, do it persistently and do it well,
his thoughts were directed to the study of Dentistry.
As a result he entered the S. D. C. in '15. After spend¬
ing three successful years he goes out to relieve suffer¬
ing humanity with the Class of 'IS.

JOHN THOMAS ENDSLEY, D.D.S.
Birmingham, Ala.
He received his preliminary education in Birming¬
ham, Ala. After spending several years in the business
world he decided to take up the profession of Dentis¬
try, and entered the Birmingham Dental College in the
Fall of '11, graduating with honors in '14. Being out
for a few years, he decided to take a post-graduate
course, entering with the Class of '18.
By his smile and ever willing hand to help others,
lie has won the friendship of all his class-mates. We
can only predict a successful future for him.
Business Manager Annual 1918.
JAMES YOUNG FOLSOM, Jr.

Marianna, Fla.
J. Y. comes to us from the '' Land of Flowers''. He
received his early education in the Jackson County High
School from which he graduated in '14, after which he
spent one year at the University of Florida. Early in
life he chose Dentistry as a profession and began the
study in the Fall of '15. He has developed into one of
the most able operators in his class. We predict for
him great success in his profession.
WILLIE BYRD FORD
Roanoke, Ala.
The chief characteristic of Ford is that he is always
loaded and achieving something. John Henry is loved
by all because he is "world wide" known. His name
indicates that he is never found in a rut and he "gets
there just the same''. He received his education at
Randolph High School, after which he decided to seek
his fame through the medium of Dentistry. Unhesitat¬
ingly we predict that Ford will win great success and
be found standing on the front in the near future.

He comes to us from the hustling City of Brooklyn,
N. Y., and received his literary education in that place;
after completing his education he was engaged for some
time in the drug business as a pharmacist, but deciding
to study Dentistry he came southward and stopped in
Atlanta, where he entered the S. D. C. Since he has
been with us he has made a number of friends by his
frank and open manner; he is always ready to help a
fellow student in any way he can. He is a hard worker
both in theory and practical work. We think he will
achieve a well merited success.
IRVIN SMITH FUTCH
Alachua, Fla.
Irvin, a fair-haired, gray-eyed Georgian, was born in
Quitman, Ga., but early in life moved to the '' Land of
Flowers'' where he received his early education in
Alachua High School from which he graduated in '14.
He was inclined to- be a farmer and merchant but a
continual reminder of Dentistry gave him the idea of
spending one year in the University in preparing for Den¬
tistry. He arrived at the S. D. C. in October, '15. He
expects to return to the '' Land of Flowers'' on com¬
pletion of his course.
STEVE ARTHUR GARRETT
Austell, Ga.
'' Steve,'' after having spent two years at Emory
College, preparatory to the study of Dentistry, entered
A. D. 0. in '15. Since that time he has been a leader
in his class and has been noted for the earnest perform¬
ance of every duty that has been placed in his charge.
We predict great success for "Steve".
Member Annual Staff 1918.

Archie received his early education at Drew High
School. He came to us in '15, has served three years
with us, and proved his ability as both a theoretical and
a practical man. Gilliland, being a man of few words,
has demonstrated that his skill and ability as an opera¬
tor shall be the characterizing feature of his life. He
being blessed with these qualities we feel confident that
his future shall be crowned with success.
JAMES STANLEY GRIFFITH
E W $
Whetesand, Miss.
'' Griff'' hails from the good old State of Mississippi.
He received his literary education in Poplarville High
School. In '10 he entered Vanderbilt University, spend¬
ing his Freshman and Junior year there, after which
he spent four years in Panama City. In '17 he returned
to the United States and entered the A. S. D. C. Since
being with us he has won the friendship of his class¬
mates and has grown to be one of us. On account of
his mechanical ability as an operator, we believe he will
meet with success.
CHALMERS DRISCOLL HADDON

Abbeville, S. C.
He obtained part of his Prep, training at Abbeville,

Eirslsing College, spending two years there. Chalmers
realized that he was put in this world for some good,
so, realizing the good he could render humanity as a
Dentist, he entered the S. D. C. in '15. Chalmers al¬
ways attends to his duties in a quiet and business-like
manner. We are all expecting a great success for him
in his chosen profession.

Graduate of Union High School; after teaching one
year in primary school, entered the Dental College;
since, he has shown a marked adherence to duty at all

EMMETTE EUGENE HARMON
Statesville, N. C.

larmon. He received his education at Eupeptic Springs,
N. C. He entered the S. D. C. in '15. His whole Col¬
lege life has been shown by those high morals and social
rineiples that are incorporated in the make-up of every
true gentleman. His success is assured and fortunate
indeed is the community in which Emmette E. Harmon
locates.

time has apparently dealt lightly with him, and his
motto, '' don't worry,'' he follows very well indeed.
He has had a wide field of experience in the business
world where he made many friends. We predict for
him great success in his profession.

In introducing this young man we call your atten¬

ceived his educational training in the Berry School after

School of Georgia, where he graduated in '13. We can

us he has been on a par with the best men of his class.
He has made many friends here with his kind, willing
disposition. We expect his sphere of friendship to grow
in the community in which he locates.
Associate Editor Annual Staff 1918.

education in the Locust Grove Institute. His father
being a Dentist before him, he also decided on the same
profession. We are pleased to have him with us. His
ready wit and humor have afforded many good hearty
laughs which alone merit our love and best wishes for
him.

dents, lie has been a hard worker while in College;
is better known by the boys to be a man who never
has much to say but is always found on the job. We
predict for him a great success In the future.

School. He delights in placing Gray's Anatomy on his

theory as well as practical work. He is an active
member of his fraternity. We predict a great future
for him.

gain his dental education. We predict a bright future
for him.

years. His mind turned to the more capable things of
life and he decided to benefit humanity as well as him¬
self by obtaining the M.D. degree. He attended the

years. He had such '' pulling ways'' he took up the

Assistant Business Manager Annual 1918.

decided to study Dentistry. He entered the A. D. C.

take a course in broken doses. He is a jolly good fel¬
low and is very popular with the boys. We are sure
that he will make a success.
CHARLES ATKINSON JOHNSON
E V $
Bowman, Ga.

father and brother being M.D.'s he was naturally led
into Medical Science, and after spending one year
in the Atlanta College of Pharmacy decided this was
not his chosen field, so in the Fall of '15 he entered
the old S. D. C. His keen insight into life and motives
all combine to make him an ideal man for this profes¬
sion. Justly should we be proud of his skill as an oper¬
ator which, combined with his personality, means un¬
bounded success.

pleting his education there. He traveled a number of
years and in '15 entered the A. D. C. He relates many
of his experiences while traveling. Not being present
we have to rely upon F. G. 's veracity as to the truth of
many of his escapades. From the beginning of his
course he has been very successful. His ability and
unrestricted application of himself to his work made for

EDGAR DOW JONES

school work at Oak Hill in the Spring of '15, and en¬
tered the A. D. C. in the fall of the same year. By
his personality he has been very popular with the entire
student body. He is a splendid conscientious operator

sion. On his departing from the A. S. D. C. we wish
for "Eddie" a most happy and successful future.
CHAS. HUNTER JONES

BARNEY BEEL KENNEDY'
Greenwood, Miss.

came to us as a pharmacist. In College work he took

profession some day.

education was received at Clemson School, and at Oak
Ridge. He is glad that he graduates this year, but is
grieved over the fact that he must leave Atlanta. Here's
predicting that he will meet with great success in his
profession.

Peoria, 111.
Lanan, after spending two years at the Louisville
College of Dentistry, came to us to complete his course
in his chosen profession. Lanon is known to be a quiet
boy and a hard thinker. Always doing his best at any¬

We like him for he is quiet and unostentatious, but

vented from returning to College after his Junior year
and graduating with his original class, but we are glad
to have him numbered among the Class of '18. Having
already had much experience in Practical Dentistry, he
is sure to make good.
JAMES KELLUM LEVIE
Atlanta, Ga.
"Jake," as he is commonly known in the drug busi¬
ness, received his education at Rome, Ga. In 1911 he
entered the Atlanta College of Pharmacy. In his Senior
year he was appointed Assistant Professor of Pharmacy.
After giving two years of his life to the aid of the suf¬
fering, he undertook a greater work, that of being a
Doctor of Dental Surgery. He has been a faithful
worker, and necessarily must some day obtain that char¬
acteristic of his type.

ARTHUR FINLEY LINK
Atlanta, Ga.
After receiving his preliminary education in the pub¬
lic schools of Atlanta, and later spending a few years
at Gordon Institute, Peacock School for Boys, and At¬
lanta School of Pharmacy, he decided to follow in his
father's footsteps and therefore entered the S. D. C. in
the Fall of '15. He is a man of high ideals, sincere
spirit, a good student, and will make a Dentist Atlanta
should be proud of. He is not much of a talker, but
possesses a rarer and much better quality as a good
listener.
QUINCE GLADSTONE LOGAN
Rutherfordton, N. C.
Logan entered our midst in the Fall of '15, after
completing his literary education at Mar's Hill and
Valparaiso University. He was drafted into the army
in the Fall of '17, but later was released from service to
finish his dental education. Logan has made a good
student and a hard worker, and is highly esteemed by
his class-mates. We predict for him a future success.
KLEBER C. MADDOX
Marietta, Ga.
Maddox is an industrious young fellow who for the
last three years has arisen at 5 a. m. in order to reach
College in time to see the doors of the lecture hall close.
We think that Uncle Sam needs an army of men with
such grit to send against the Kaiser. During these three
years, in his quiet kind of way, he has labored diligently,
and has always made good in his work. We feel sure
that he will be equally as successful in the practice of
his profession.

"Mac" is a jolly good fellow. After finishing
graded schools he graduated from L. M. I. in '12, and
entered our midst in '15. He is a good mixer and has
many friends among us to his credit. By diligent ap¬
plication he has established for himself a reputation of
which we are justly proud. His many friends believe
a brilliant future is in store for him and expect to hear
great things from him in his chosen field—Oral Surgery.

Waynesville, N. C.
Medford was born near Waynesville, N. O, and
from that time he has shown what was in him by the
'' get-up-and-get'' type of energy which has always
been his. It almost goes without saying that he is quite
popular with the fairer sex, and it is a sure thing that
he will have a considerable number in his practice.
He is a man who talks not over-much, but says some¬
thing worth while when he does speak.
Vice-president Class 1916- '17.

Right in the beginning of his Freshman year he
made a record for himself as an operator that he has

have made his work light. He has shown quite a bit of
skill in inlay work. Mercer received his early education
in Piedmont High School in Western North Carolina

Mills was born and received his early education in

and was employed by the various telegraph companies.

been a most diligent and successful student. We predict
for him-a great success in his profession.
Secretary to Editor-in-Chief Annual 1918.
LONNIE W. MITCHELL

Mitchell is one of those jolly go-lucky fellows who

Hattiesburg High Schools and the South Mississippi
College. In '15 Mitchell decided to study Dentistry and
entered the A. D. C. From the beginning Mitchell made
good and we are forcibly impressed with that fact, be¬
cause lately he entered the matrimonial field and suc¬
ceeded there as well as he did in College.
ITALY MARGUERITE MORSE
East Bend, N. C.
The village of East Bend honors itself and this Col¬
lege by the presence in the '18 Class of one of its most

Spring of '15 and in the Fall of the same year she en¬
tered the A. D. C. Since that time she has been an
honest, earnest and capable student. She is quiet and
holds a much-to-be-desired position in the Class, and is
admired by every member of it. Her work, both tech¬
nical and theoretical, has been of the highest type, which,
combined with her refinement and gentility, assure for
her a successful career.
Associate Editor Annual 1918.

Mr. Murphey entered the A. D. C. in October, '15,

ulty by his determination to succeed. He has a very
striking personality which is felt by all those with
whom he associates. As an operator he is one of the
best; and with the reputation of being able to "deliver

mates by his readiness to lend anything he possesses.

lege his life has been characterized by those high moral

make-up of every true gentleman. He has made excel¬
lent records in theory and his practical work.
WILLIAM GEORGE NIMOCKS
Fayetteville, N. C.
"Little in stature but big in heart." This little

als and much brilliancy of mind he will sooner or later

Senior Class Poem
In the dim uncertain future,
When the years have passed us by,
Will recollections of the Past
Be accompanied by a sigh?
Or will the memories reminiscent
Of our lives bring no regret,
Or will our attainments be as many
As we fondly now expect.'
Has each man fulfilled his duty,
Living up to high ideals,
As a retrospective glance
At his well-done work he steals'?
Or has he long since realized,
That as Life's race is nearly run,
His boyhood plans for the Future
Must forever remain undone?
Therefore, think long and soundly—
Ponder well on these things agleam,
And on the roll of Fame and Greatness,
Write many names of the Class '18.
H. W. Catron,
Senior Class History
DURING the Fall of 1915 "Dr. Shep" and "Dr. Claude" spent much of their
valuable time corresponding with boys whose names they could get ranging
from nineteen to thirty-one years old. They used such high sounding
phrases that they thoroughly succeeded in convincing the young men that life was
not worth living without the degree of D.D.S.
On October 1st, 1915, about 150 boys and girls from every walk of life came
to Atlanta, each having a great ambition to be a dental surgeon. On entering the
Dean's Office we were greeted with a smile and a "Glad to see you Mr. ----, have
a seat." After extracting $200.00 of our hard-earned money we left the office
with a tap on the back and these words, "All right. Doctor, call again."
Life became different, at least with the boys. Two "Saturday nights" each
week, a shave every other day and a tonic twice a week on our "Charlie Chaplin"
mustache, a seat each week in the "peanut" gallery of a vaudeville show, was our
procedure for the first year. We were strictly Freshmen.
Our professors were "mighty big-" men in those days, and how we would
tremble when they would utter such phrases as "Squamous epithelium," "Strep¬
tococcus viridans." "Levator labii superioris alaeque nasi." To all this we became
accustomed and side-tracked our discussion to "Bush-whacking. "State Board,"
and "Locating in some big city."
After the usual joys of a Summer vacation, once more we find ourselves in
Atlanta. At this time we begin carving on the human cadaver (which means
elimination of hash from the menu). Now, to find the gastrocnemius muscle,
locate the solar plexus, learn how to bound the quadrilateral triangle, trace the
blood from incisor to great phalanges, learn the function of the various muscles:
Orbicularis oris, orbicularis palpebrarum, corrugator supercilli, compressor narium
minor. After digesting all of this we realized that superior maxillary only meant
the upper jaw, and that stomatitis didn't mean inflammation of the stomach.
Now, I pray and beseech you that you don't breathe through the oesophagus, nor
swallow through the foramen magnum; and ye gods! learn how to spell symphysis,
and don't put two s's in "pus." Young gentlemen. I would have you to learn
that sodium and potassium carbonates increase the viscosity of the blood. We
have long since learned to recognize the familiar words in pathology lecture,
"Where are you my son?" and the reply to the answer. "Thank you, boy." In
radiology it is "a-b-s-o-l-u-t-e-l-y" essential to know how to adjust the X-ray tube.
Much of our valuable time was required in securing necessary skill, proper
technique, and learning how to properly distribute heat; and for a little real taste
of life's work we made crowns of all descriptions, using a piece of solder the size
of a gnat's eve. constructing bridges and burning our hackings, cracking our fac¬
ings, but for this we gritted our teeth and said nothing. To the mouth we went;
lirst thing we found was a fourteen year old boy with exposed pulp iu a six year
molar. We tried to adjust the rubber dam and we repeated "dam" and left off the
Hsal9l8ttiniiiiiiiiiii[|||,
m%
rubber until the demonstrator came, and we would plead for him to adjust the
"dam."' The demonstrator would say ,"A11 right, son. hut you must remember
there is no royal road to dentistry."
With our last year came the period of looking through microscopes at va¬
rious kinds of bugs, locating the normal artery in a tadpole's tail, and observing
the various changes of inflammation in living tissue. In the physiological labora¬
tory we experimented with frogs, trying to find out where the croak came from,
pithing the frog to eliminate pain while dissecting the gastrocnemius muscle,
sciatic nerve and exposing the heart to get a kymographic record of the heart's
beat.
As Seniors, there was a great deal expected and required of us. We were re¬
quired to put. in 050 gold fillings, 500 synthetics, and to do other work in propor¬
tion. To avoid the display of gold, some got off two specimen fillings in one cavity,
while others had various demonstrators to grade the same filling. From the Fresh¬
men came some valuable requests for information on dentistry; you don't know
what it means unless you have been there.
Still, as we come to close, sadness prevails when we realize how little we
know and how much we need to know to practice dental surgery as it should be
practiced today.
Yet as we have progressed from various paths of life to members of the grad¬
uating Class of '18, so shall we progress from the recent graduate to a position of
esteem; and as recognized leaders of communities in which we locate, our people
shall know us as dental surgeons of ability, and benefactors to suffering humanity.
So reads the history of the Class of '18 from the "peanut" ticket of the vaude¬
ville show October, 1915, to box seats in the Atlanta Theatre for graduating exer¬
cises May 29th, 1918.
H. L. Parks, Historian.

Senior Class Prophecy
O
NCE upon a time there traveled in the olden countries prophets and bards who
went from place to place and would prophesy and sing of omens either good
or had. Having read of these I always had a desire to see and hear one,
especially at this time, as it would greatly aid me in seeing into the future of my
friends, which has always interested me. I so expressed myself to my closest friend
and classmate. Bob Ingram. Knowing nearly everyone in Atlanta, he immediately
told me where we could find this man who, by some power, could prophesy.
We went to his home and having made known my desire he willingly agreed
to help me out. He suggested various means of accomplishing our purpose, but
Bob suggested that we go out to the Aviation School at Georgia Tech, get a ma¬
chine and travel from place to place, of to use glasses, thinking they would give
us a farther insight into the mysteries that we wished to delve into.
We had to assemble the machine, but Bob being a pretty good mechanic, we
succeeded in a very short while.
We ascended, in what direction we do not know, because we left all apparatus
of direction and altitude finding down on the ground (being nothing uncommon,
for a mechanic always leaves half of his tools in the road). I looked for the
glasses but could not find them, but leave it to an "old head" to come to the rescue.
Bob handed me two empty beer bottles and said they would answer the purpose.
(He and our other companion must have emptied them, for if 1 had had one full
1 would not have needed any more of an inspiration to prophesy for anything or
anybody.)
Taking the two bottles and raising them to my eyes I looked and behold I
saw two tiny specks on the ground. Looking at my map 1 saw it was near Charles¬
ton, S. C, and looking through my bottles again I saw it was my two friends,
F. Y. Smith and Patrick. It seemed as though I could hear them calling, "Shrimp
and mullet," "Shrimp and mullet!" I was so surprised that I turned my head in
shame toward Seneca, S. C, and saw H. C. Rippy running a steam shovel, prepar¬
ing the ground for a garage, in order to give Brooks Connor, Jr.. a job, and afford
Chalmers Haddon a more pleasant occupation than catching dogs, for which he has
quite a reputation.
I saw a beautiful farm stretching for miles away with all manner of fruits and
vegetables laid off in symmetrical figures. I thought I could distinguish J. T. Put-
ledge and Carl Busbee and John McCabe working side by side. I turned to my old
companion, he said that he had often heard of them, but that they were only hired
help.
Having seen enough where I thought was the State of South Carolina, I raised
my bottles slightly and saw in the State of North Carolina the town of Fayette-
ville. We decided to land at the hotel. I found C. C. Steele answering calls for
ice water.
*m
!P5Qe>l8£?Hf
Wa
tt:i
I thought I'd better telegraph home and let them know where we were. Whom
should I meet at the telegraph office but my old friend D. L. Pridgen picking at
a telegraph instrument just like he was picking out an old amalgam filling. Prid¬
gen insisted on taking us around town. Being tired and thirsty we dropped into
a soda stand and found our dear old brother, Dickey, engaged in the high art of
"slinging slop." We had just finished our drink and some fellow pushed in be¬
tween us with saw dust all over him. His beard \vras so heavy you couldn't tell
whether he was white or black, but I noticed a peculiar twang in his speech, and
lo and behold I discovered it was J. Cecil Crank, from Virginia, down in that
country running a saw mill. Discussing olden times at the A.-S. D. C. the ques¬
tion was asked if any one knew the whereabouts of W. C. Current. Crank said he
thought he belonged to the Internal Revenue Department, running down stills, be¬
cause that was about all he did when in College.
We said good-bye and resumed our flying trip and looking around through my
bottle I saw far away the town of Hickory. It was just growing dark and suddenly
there flashed a big electric sign, "Yount & Campbell, Painless Dentists." I was
somewhat surprised, but my companions assured me that they would soon find the
error of their ways and return to the fold.
I tried hard to see more by night but the fog was thick, so landing seemed
advisable. We saw the lights of Waynesville, N. C, and "dropped in." We found
the town somewhat astir and decided to investigate. On entering a large wooden
structure we were handed a program headed "Farmers' Convention." Feeling at
home we decided to stay. I read my program and whose name should I see but
some of my former classmates. N. M. Medford being chairman pro tern, called the
meeting to order. The opening address was given by M. J. Doub, of East Bend, on
"The Proper Spreading of Fertilizer" (Bull). Next on the program was a solo by
Alex Newton, who was ably assisted at the piano by Miss lone Turner. Among
other speakers of note were Thrailkill and C. H. Bryan, of Apex, N. C, E. E. Har¬
mon, Jr., B. C. Thomasson and E. D. Jones. Being a little hesitant about leaving,
as it was raining, we were politely informed by J. L. West and L. J. Dupree that
as all the lamps had to be blown out we would have to leave.
Wishing to keep as dry as possible, we stepped out on the sidewalk and saw a
movie across the street. We went in and found to our amazement that other friends
of ours were there, as there stood before us two perfectly groomed ushers in the
form of Poindexter and F. G. Johnson. We learned that a special program had been
put on that day for the benefit of the "Convention." Much to our delight, our
friend. Bill Nimocks, stepped out and sang "The Lost Chord"—a voice of rather
pleasing quality, but not the same voice he had while in College. I was sorry for
I was sure that dissipation was the cause.
We waited until after Bill had finished (honestly) and took him to dinner.
Not knowing a good restaurant ourselves, we asked Bill where he ate. He confided
to me that he was not making much money, he always ate down at the "Beanery,"
as it was cheap and that he had a friend that worked there whom we would probably
remember. As we walked in we found that it was none other than J. F. West
Sfeji
j^Tl9l8g^[
m
"slinging hash." He had some real estate too, he informed us though, he only
worked there to pass away the time (and incidentally got something to eat).
After leaving Waynesville we thought we might find some one in Tennessee.
Our seer companion thought that he had visions of P. W. Warrenfells and S. A.
Garrett becoming as famous as "Four Poses." Sure enough, we found them. They
seemed to be somewhat downcast, and inquiring as to the cause of their feelings, I
found that Randolph Rose was closing out, and as a consequence they would be out
of a job. They said that they had other friends in the same predicament. They
mentioned the name of E. I. White as one. The first thing I thought of was a
picture of White going back to his old job, shoving a hot iron across a pair of pants.
We extended our sympathy, which on second thought, I don't think was appreciated
very much, but we said good-bye and arose into the air quietly and traveled towards
Bristol. We saw the sign of a dance hall, and entering, found that it was a con¬
test dance, in which our old friend Barkley was participating. He was nearly worn
out and we tried to make him stop, knowing that he was a little delicate (he eats
lettuce), but were awarded a surprise by seeing a cup given him (we don't know
what was in it, but Bob insisted that he heard ivories) for he had danced seven and
a half hours without stopping. He really wasn't dancing, he was only walking like
a land-lubber, because he had been in the navy so long that it was his natural walk.
He was quite exhausted and I went out to get a stimulant (for Barkley) and found
Friedman "slinging suds." While waiting for service I felt some one rubbing a
mop over my feet. I started to "bawl him out," but found it was my friend, Thos.
F. Beam. He said he was rooming with the two Nolans, but as they were with a
circus on the road we would miss them, but we had an idea we would strike the
show in some town, somewhere, so we were not worried. I think Sunderman was
road agent for the show, but am not sure.
We started towards Arkansas, but not seeing much we only made one stop,
and that was in Prattsville, and found Hope. "Where there's life, there's Hope."
On trying to ascend we found that there was some trouble with the engine. I
think our mechanic was sick of his job, for he suggested that we ship our machine
to an aviation school in Texas and exchange it for a better one. We put the ma¬
chine on the train and got on ourselves, although we had a hard time getting enough
money together to buy three tickets, but by arguing with the ticket agent we got
a discount, it being bargain day.
The first one to pass through the train with his wares around his neck was
J. R. Tucker. We were a little timid about acknowledging our acquaintance, owing
to the crowded condition of the car, but he wouldn't miss us. But we were glad
to see him as he gave us some bananas (which made us all sick, for they were old
enough to "vote"). Our recovery was quick, due to the presence of mind of our ild
friend, C. R. Brice, who was on his way to Texas for his health. Owing to his vast
knowledge of Materia Medica he immediately administered an emetic, and our
thanks go to him for the completion of our trip. During the commotion, who
should rush up and begin asking questions but Belford, which reminded us vividly
of our classroom days. His many questions were answered by H. W. Catron, of
Hancock County. Tenn., who was on his way to attend the Annual High School
Janitors' Convention. The conductor came along to get our tickets. He looked at
our tickets and then at us, and behold! before our very eyes stood C. C. Bennett.
He had been "railroading" since his graduation, since that had appealed to him
more than pulling "offending organs of mastication."
We heard a familiar voice somewhere in the crowd but could not place it. I
asked for my beer bottles that I might look and see from whence it came. We
couldn't find but one bottle and looking through it 1 could clearly see that it was
J. Y. Turner, who was taking a bunch of his school children on an excursion.
They all looked like his own, but I was assured by my seer companion that they
were not. for he said he was well acquainted with Turner and he knew the limit
of his possibilities.
We and our machine reached our destination. Bob wanted to swap the ma¬
chine for a horse, but I didn't want to cheat anybody, so we had it fixed up as
good as possible. We were in need of oil. We stopped a fellow rigged up in a
cow-boy regalia. To our surprise, it was A. L. Wetsel. He was pretty gruff, but
informed us where we could get oil. We saw a sign, "Oils & Gasoline—Specially
Tested. L. G. Smith, Prop." We went in. He wanted to overcharge us, but we
wouldn't let him do that on account of old friendship. R. L. Wood left a "crap
game" long enough to put it into the machine and we were off again.
We headed in the direction of Georgia. Passing through the State of Missis¬
sippi we saw some soldiers camping. We "dropped in." We found B. B. Ken¬
nedy mixing dough. He said it beat mixing drugs because there was no danger.
We found Harbour cooking, and oh my! if those boys lived through it, it was a
miracle! He cooked that bread just like he was heating an investment, ready to
make a cast. The boys came in and amongst them were H. Wilson and A. J.
Mills. They said they would rather be practicing dentistry, but the fortunes of
war were theirs, and that they were nephews of their rich Uncle Sam.
We left there and flew over to Montgomery. We saw a tiny white speck on a
big boulevard, and raising my bottles to my eyes distinguished Joseph Rutland
engaged in the peaceful pursuit of manicuring a boulevard, being assisted by our
old friend. Lewis Douglas. We saw a little further up the street J. S. Griffith with
a bunch of Panama laborers repairing some sewer piptes which had bursted. I saw
a crowd on a corner, and from what I could see by straining my eyes severely, was
Mississippi Jones demonstrating to a bunch of negroes how he could pull their
teeth by conductive anesthesia without hurting them for fifty cents. His patients
were reluctant about trying his skill, for J. T. P]ndsley was there trying to sell
them life insurance before undertaking anything of tnat kind. Evidently, this
was an unusual sight, for I could see just behind the crowd Hunter Allen drawing
a cartoon for a local paper of the incident.
There appeared to be a little excitement. I rubbed my bottles so I could get
a better vision, and saw G. W. Eason trying to get Mississippi to lower his price,
which had enraged him very much. They were quickly separated by a policeman
who was none other than A. H. Coker. That job suited him, for all he did before
entering college was to walk the streets.
By this time we had reached the State of Louisiana. I saw the sign of a den¬
tist, and naturally being interested I looked closer and found that F. D. Henry
had been spending his time since he graduated crowning "shine teeth" for seventy-
five cents per. As it was time to partake of our daily repast, we descended and
found to our surprise that we were in Cheneyville. Remembering that our dear
old friend, Rutledge, was from that metropolis, we immediately inquired for him.
The gentleman to whom we referred our inquiry, looked on us with some disgust
and asked us if it was necessary for him to have to direct us to the biggest "ladies'
man" in the State of Louisiana. Bang! came our memory back to us, for was it
not C. E. Rutledge who put Spring Street on the map of Atlanta ? We saw him
to talk to and we saw him to listen to. We found, however, that he had a close
second in the person of R. C. Murphy, and oh my! that baritone voice of Murphy's
was just so captivating that he would sit on a fence and sing and the girls would
come to him like hunting dogs answering a horn. We had to leave hurriedly.
We got over into Georgia and hit Savannah. Here we tried to land. Bob
"cut off" too soon and we landed much quicker than anticipated. Some one called
for an ambulance and when it came who should be driving it but Armona. He
simply worked there to be with the nurses. On the way to the hospital a "skirt"
waved at him and he stopped to talk to her, but we couldn't stand that, and after
much persuasion we succeeded in getting him to take us on. (We don't know
whether she was white or black. Bob said he had a pretty good idea but he
wouldn't like to say.)
Well, there we were in the hospital. It was quite a large one, too. We found
Miss Italy Morse and Miss Helen Robinson in training as nurses, for they desired
to do their bit. They informed us that a tramp steamer had been damaged, and
amongst the hands on board were Steve Baldwin, C. R. Munford, Reed, Rainer,
J. K. Levie, Cheney, K. C. Maddox, Bill Hogan (fireman), Carr, G. 0. Wheless,
C. A. Johnson. Of course we were a little surprised, but we found that they
wanted to go to France and thought that the best way. As it was, they landed in
the hospital.
A doctor came to examine us, and finding nothing the matter but a severe
shock, decided we had better rest for a few days.
Connected with the hospital was a farm, from which it supported itself. We
were taken for an outing to see the farm. There we found G. B. Head and Sam
Easley digging potatoes. Donald White was taking a litter of pigs for a walk;
Frank Wesley was feeding the stock; H. C. Bugg was cutting corn; Link was milk¬
ing the cows, and Burger and Needham were shucking corn. Kurfees was walk¬
ing around like he owned the place, but we found much to our sorrow that he was
slightly "off," and they had only slight hopes of his recovery. Folsom was super¬
intendent and a good one.
They dismissed us in due time, but liking Savannah pretty well, we stayed
a few days. We dropped in a movie to see Beverly Bayne. Who should be her
leading man but V. J. Altee. We always knew that he would be a leading movie
actor. He was assisted by a most notable cast, including the now famous names
of such men as Irvin Futch, G. F. Altee, P. C. Blount, and H. A. Benton.
W\
Leaving the next morning we arrived in Atlanta that evening. Not being
very tired and fond of dancing, we dropped in Lane's Dance Hall. We tried to
get by the ticket man. but were stopped by him. We found him to he none other
than our old chum, Frank Lentz. lie had been at it since graduating, and had
made a success apparently.
There were quite a few soldiers up there and among them were Ilartslield,
Bussell (now grey-headed), Callahan. Gilliland, II. I-]. Wood. Weatherman. C. 0.
Wells (playing a bass drum in orchestra), Rubin, M. M. Parks, .1. II. Nicholson,
Hunter (singing Dutch songs in Italian), and several other novelties, hut being
tired we departed.
Having thanked our kind friend for his guidance and companionship, and
rewarded him for his time, we separated, each unto his own way, and the Prophet
still lives.
H. W. McDonald.

Valedictory
Mr. President, Fellow Classmates, Members of the Faculty, Ladies and Gentlemen:
TO the friends gathered here and to our faculty who have been our guides it
remains my privilege, only, to give a last greeting. Our last moments of
college days are fast ebbing away. Our pulses are growing feeble, our
breath falters and only time and energy for one more word is left. Our minds are
under two great forces, memory and hope. Of memory, as we look back over the
years now ended, which have given us a portion of student life, and unlike any
other have furnished experience from the power of which this life is too brief to
free us. Of hope, as each one stands questioning his own future. With just what
words shall I best gather up the whole meaning of this moment? We know well
you object to the old English phrase, "Good-bye," on the ground that it is too
often said by college boys, and as a rule it is too hopeless; that it possesses no at¬
tempt to disguise or remove the feelings which a writer has so well expressed,
"In every parting there is an image of death." But it seems to me to be the most
appropriate word for this occasion, for in a deep sense our parting is real and
final.
To you, the people of this fair city, it would never be possible to even begin
to express our feeling of gratitude for all you have done for us. We came into
your midst quietly but we celebrate our departure on tomorrow to pursue the mis¬
sion we have chosen in the great outer world. We would pause in the deepest
sadness when we think of the one word that draws down the curtain upon the
brightest scenes of earthly life—that word to give utterance to which we have
assembled here tonight—that sad, sweet word, "Farewell." But friends, I would
not feel that I have done my classmates justice without saying that we have heard
the trumpet call of our country. As we go from our college and your city, we
go to join with the millions who are giving their all, their last measure of devotion,
their last drop of blood. Our own flesh and blood is dedicated to this struggle, to
quench this hell of fire, of rage and destruction, to subdue our enemies who are
the vilest and who have committed the most insane and beastly acts ever per¬
formed by animated beings masquerading in the form of man. Tender years,
decrepit age, budding womanhood and honored motherhood have long since ceased
to mean anything to them. I speak the sentiments of my classmates when I tell
you that we grasp the greatest opportunity that has ever come to us to aid your
sons and brothers in checking this incarnate fiend which has been unchained and
emerges from the cesspools of hell to belch forth its noisome blast of iniquity and
drag its fetid clamoring shapes over God's sacred footstool; to irreparably blight
the choicest flower His infinite mind has fashioned. But to return to the thought,
we thank vou for the care and interest you have taken in our welfare, and as we
bid you adieu, believe that we will ever cherish in our hearts the thought that to
a great extent we owe to you, the privileges we have enjoyed, and at this moment
these privileges seem the most grand and dear to us. These thoughts cause us to
»m
ff55lftl8K51
ws

• MB
extend a parting hand to you with emotions of especial regret. Farewell, fair city;
farewell, friends tried and true; farewell, scenes and places which time can never
erase from our mind's fond recollections.
Gentlemen of the Faculty: To you has been given the task of impressing
directly upon our minds those truths that shall develop the truest manhood of each
one's nature, and of implanting in each brain and heart the germ of knowledge,
whose perfect growths shall form lives of success and whose fruitage be the crown¬
ing of well spent lives. How well you have discharged these responsibilities the
present but faintly shows; the future alone can tell. Professors, at your feet we
have so often sat. your patience we have so often tried, your best laid plans we have
so often foiled by our heedlessness. We come tonight to voice our appreciation for
your labors which are to be impressing and powerful influences on our lives. We
tremble as we leave you, for here we have relied on your wisdom, your guidance.
Here we have sought your counsel and assistance. Now, we launch our little craft
away from the masterbuilder's hands. We go to battle where there shall be none
to assist. If ever dark days of defeat and failure come, bitterly will we regret our
negligence. We have spent three important years of our lives under your care and
we cannot refrain from expressing the deep sense of obligation that rests upon us.
Let us assure you that we leave your college with a firm purpose to live so as to
add new honor to it and to the dental profession as well. We thank you for the
sacrifices you have made for us. We cannot repay you, and promises are but empty
forms. Now, in the name of my class, I bid you farewell, with the hope that your
memory of us may be as pleasant as ours shall always be of you.
Classmates, our college days are ended. Here we drank from the same foun¬
tains, had the same brave thoughts and high aspirations for the future. Think not
that all is sunshine, nor that fame will wait upon your bidding, for it has been well
said, "He that would win must labor for the prize." But I would not dwell upon
this theme; let the success of others be your stimulus. The solemn thought that
this may be the last time that our class will meet unbroken chills and awes every
heart. Forgetting as we do all heart wounds of class rivalry, let us bear away
from this place the precious casket of our strong true love, and as the parting
word is said, let us go to our labors resolved each one to play the part of a real
man. May we enter this beginning of a new life in every degree of earnestness,
for it behooves us to step cautiously as we cross the threshold and emerge upon the
dazzling sunlight and deafening ears of a busy world. Comrades, farewell. May
prosperity be with each one, and if our next meeting be in the Great Hereafter.
may an unclouded path of glorious labor, toil and triumph lead back and back
amid and beyond the scenes of times life to this time and to this spot where now
we say farewell.
C. C. Bennett.

Wear a Smile
Learn to know as you jog along
The value of a smile—
A glint of sunlight on your face
Just as you meet the while.
It speaks a measure of its own
To strangers and to friend;
So wear a smile and pass it on,
'Twill pay you in the end.
The loads which other souls must bear
Will somewhat lighter grow,
Because you meet them with a smile,
And keep your heart aglow,
And some day they will smile on you,
When you are not aware,
And chase the shadows from your heart
When you are press 'd by care.
Aside from this, God says, '' Be kind,''
This world is full of tears;
And love alone has might to change
The color of the years;
So catch the summer of His skies
And count the art worth while;
And as you trudge along life's road
Just wear a cheery smile.
Selected.

Junior Class Poem
Only one short year has passed
Since we were the Freshman (Mass,
And how we'd splatter plaster was some fun.
But now we 're really Juniors,
One more year and we'll be Seniors,
Then our funny splattering will be done.
For we '11 have to brave the tide
Without Hughes or Foster for our guide,
And I fear sometimes the waves will beat us down;
But with '' pluggers, " " probes'' and '' pullers''
We can build a craft of '' dollars,''
And if on this "boat," no one will ever drown.
But just here 'tis sad to note
That before we build our boat,
We may have to ride one built by U. S. A.
We won 't need our '' probes'' or " pullers,''
Nor will we need any dollars,
For on this boat our Uncle Sammy pays our way.
And so if by luck or chance
We safely land in France,
We '11 still hope to be a D.D.S. some day.
But if we shoulder guns
And march out against the Huns
All our Dental hopes will fade away.
We '11 then think what kind of men
We have, or should have been;
And if our chance for a "better place" seems fair,
Then our only hope or guide
Will be in Him who rules the tide
To bring us back or leave us '' over there.''
Cecil A. Pless.
Junior Class History
THE first of October, 1916, found every man who ever thought of studying
dentistry on his way to Atlanta to matriculate with either the Atlanta or
Southern Dental College for doctors of dental surgery. From among their
number could be found boys just out of their knee pants to men whose hair was
mingled with gray. This being the last chance to matriculate in the three-year
course, was the cause of such an onrush.
The history of our throwing plaster and burning our fingers while trying to
set up teeth cannot be told in these pages, and our experience in the operatory,
cleaning teeth and putting in cement and amalgam fillings will need be kept a
secret.
We all passed up our Freshman work satisfactory to the respective faculties,
thus being ready for our Junior year.
During the Summer we were notified that the two colleges had consolidated
and would become the Atlanta-Southern Dental College. Thus it was that these
two great classes were thrown together to form a still greater one, one hundred and
thirty-three in number.
On the opening day we met our new faculty, who gave us a word of welcome
and encouragement. Our first move was to secure a crown and bridge outfit and
after being given a demonstration on making shell crowns, we began to make
"Cans" (shell crowns). Then came pin crowns, bridges, swage plates, etc.
The history of our experience with these things must be told by each indi¬
vidual member of the class.
One of our most interesting, yet dreaded tasks, was dissecting. We were
promised four months, but got six. On the first day we gathered together our
gowns, gloves, dissecting instruments and Gray's Anatomy and entered the dissec¬
ting room, feeling as though we were entering into the land of the dead never to
return and some of the fellows did not return more than was absolutely necessary.
We do not believe in fasting, however, we found it more pleasant than eating for
awhile. Nevertheless, our able demonstrators made it very interesting and profit¬
able for us.
To our regret Uncle Sam called some of our demonstrators and lecturers who
had enlisted, into service. Yet we were glad to give them to such a noble cause.
A number of our class was in the service when school opened but were released
after joining the dental reserve. It became necessary for most of us to enlist in
the Medical Reserve Corps in order to get deferred classification that we might
be able to finish our course.
It was not possible for us to get through the year without some kind of epi¬
demic, and so most of us had to remain in our rooms from one to three weeks with
mumps. Smallpox also broke out and some were sent to the pest house while the
others were vaccinated, then came the time of sore arms just when we were swag¬
ing our metal plates.
The rest of our history must remain untold until you hear from us as Seniors.
Chas. S. McCall, Historian.

Freshman Class Poem
A bright, industrious class
Is the Class of '21,
And the finals, we are sure to pass,
For this is what we 've done.
We have learned the use of phenol,
And various other drugs,
Which prevent the growth of all
The microscopic '' bugs.''
We've learned to carve a tooth,
With all its grooves and ridges;
To know that cleaning teeth in youth
Prevents the use of bridges.
In Prosthetics, each has done his bit;
Our work now lies on a shelf.
If you really don't believe it,
Just go take a look yourself.
Dentition we can give in full,
And of the teeth describe their structure;
And name the bones of the skull
That form the lambdoid suture.
We 've traced the process of cell division
Through all its different phases;
And we 've met with Dr. Hinman
On his fifty-fifty basis.
With all this learned, we will not '' bust,''
But yet our work is mere' begun,
For we are only Freshmen—just
The Class of '21.
W. S. Duncan, Poet.
Freshman Class History
TEUE it is that everything that hath life has a history. Certainly then, the
Freshman Class has a record of events worthy to be inscribed upon the pages
of history, for it has proved that it is not only a live class, but a working
class. We, the Class of 1921, assembled in the Atlanta-Southern Dental College
on October 10, 1918, with proud expectant hearts, yet with some foreboding and
misgivings. It was here that we awoke to the realization that we have started out
on our future life's work, duties and responsibilities.
In spite of our short stay in College, the appeal made by our esteemed pro¬
fession for our early awakening to the colossal possibilities that our profession
hands out to us, has not been made altogether in vain.
In fact many of our most precious classmates have already looked into the
future as far as human eyes can see, and have seen the glory of the world and all
the wonders that will be. They are daily contriving to fit themselves under some
distinctive service in our chosen field that will not only be a benefit to man, but
will necessarily because of the fact, contribute to the future honor of the institu¬
tion. We already have formulated the hope that some member of our body may
distinguish himself and cause our fellow citizens to rise up and call our institu¬
tion blessed, by a distinct contribution in research and practice.
True to that old axiom, "In the Spring a young man's fancy lightly turns to
thoughts of love, etc.." two of our members succumbed to that irresistible duo,
the "wiles of cupid," plus the wonderful moonlight of early Spring; and on
March 24th, Miss Kate LeNoir, a charming member of our class, became the bride
of Mr. R. D. Ackerman. This came as a pleasant surprise to us all, the above be¬
ing two of our most popular members. We wish them much success and happi¬
ness for the many years to come.
As we close our first year of College, let us determine that the coming year
shall be even more successful. While the greater part of our history remains to be
made, let us remember that we have entered the Atlanta-Southern with a high
and noble purpose, and that only by concentrated effort and consistency to purpose
can we attain our ideals and develop into the noblest and best type of the race,
so as to render the best services to our country and fellowmen.
L. T. Daniel, Historian.

A Story of a Violet
Lingering on the hillside, he watched with rapturous gaze
A wondrous scene, the sunset, with all its brilliant rays.
'' How beautiful,'' he murmured; but did not stoop to see
That 'neath his foot upon the sod was wrought a tragedy.
For while he viewed enraptured, the glorious western sky,
He'd crushed a little violet that grew obscure and shy.
But the golden sun while setting had witnessed what took place;
And a look of pain and sadness appeared to cross his face.
'' Oh, heedless man,'' he seemed to say in anguish and despair,
'' You have spoiled my handiwork which I have cherished there.
" I 've chased away the winter, and brought the spring about,
And shed my brightest, warmest rays to coax that flower out.''
The sun then wrapped in sorrow, slowly sank from sight;
And soon the twilight shadows gave place to final night.
Then about the little hillside there hung a misty cloud;
Some thought 'twas merely rising fog, methinks 'twas
Nature's shroud.
All thru that night of silence, the stars a vigil kept.
'Tis said, that for a time all Nature must have wept;
For lo, when morning came again, the whole hillside was wet,
Ah, not with dew, but glistening tears shed for the violet.
J. Y. Turner.

Why Should the Spirit of Mortal Be Proud?
Oh! why should the spirit of mortal De proud?
Like a swift-fleeting meteor, a fast-flying cloud,
A flash of the lightning, a break of the wave,
He passeth from life to his rest in the grave.
The leaves of the oak and the willow shall fade,
Be scattered around, and together be laid;
And the young and the old, and the low and the high,
Shall molder to dust, and together shall lie.
The infant a mother attended and loved;
The mother that infant's affection who proved;
The husband, that mother anil infant who blest—
Each, all, are away to their dwellings to rest.
The hand of the king that the scepter hath borne,
The brow of the priest that the miter has worn,
The eye of the sage, and the heart of the brave,
Are hidden and lost in the depths of the grave.
The peasant, whose lot was to sow and to reap,
The herdsman, who climbed with his goats up the steep,
The beggar, who wandered in search of his bread,
Have failed away like the grass that we tread.
So the multitude goes—like the flower or the weed
That withers away to let others succeed;
So the multitude comes—even those we behold,
To repeat every tale that has often been told."
For we are the same our fathers have been;
We see the same sights our fathers have seen;
We drink the same stream, we view the same sun,
And run the same course our fathers have run.
The thoughts we are thinking, our fathers would think;
From the death we are shrinking, our fathers would shrink;
To the life we are clinging, they also would cling;
But it speeds from us all like a bird on the wing.
They loved—but the story we can not unfold;
They scorned—but the heart of the haughty is cold;
They grieved—but no wail from their slumber will come;
They joyed—but the tongue of their gladness is dumb.
Yea! hope and despondency, pleasure and pain,
Are mingled together in sunshine and rain;
And the smile and the tear, the song and the dirge,
Still follow each other, like surge upon surge.
'Tis a wink of an eye— 'tis the draught of a breath—
From the blossom of health to the paleness of death.
From the gilded salon to the bier and the shroud—
Oh! why should the spirit of mortal be proud ?
—Selected.

A Few Don'ts
Don't say, '' I see right through you,''
Although this may be true.
While you are reading others,
They, too, are reading you.
Don't lean on other people,
Put your shoulder to the wheel,
You will soon find many missions
At your shrine—to kneel.
Don't forget to mind your business.
Experience often shows
We gain but small advantage
When we tread on other 's toes.
Don't neglect the laws of health,
Whatever else you do—
With this one priceless blessing lost
Life holds but naught for you.
Don't forget financial help
When some friend needs a boost.
Favors shown in need, like chickens
Oft come home to roost.
Don 't pour your woes and sorrows
In other people's ears,
They can't carry double burdens
For their own increase with years.
Don't allow repeated failures
To discourage noble aim.
Where there is a will a way is found
Our object to attain.
Marjorie Field.

The Better Thing
It is better to lose with a conscience clean
Than to win by a trick unfair;
It is better to fail and know you 've been,
Whatever the prize was, square,
Than to claim the joy of a far off goal
And the cheers of the standers-by,
And to know deep down in your inmost soul
A cheat you must live and die.
Who wins by trick may take the prize
And at first he may think it sweet,
But many a day in the future lies
When he '11 wish he had met defeat.
For the man who lost will be glad at heart
And walk with his head up high,
While his conqueror knows he must play the par
Of a cheat and a living lie.
The prize seems fair when the fight is on,
But save it is truly won
You will hate the thing when the crowds are gone
For it stands for a false deed done.
And it's better you should never reach your goal
Than ever success to buy
At the price of knowing down deep in your soul
That your glory is all a lie.
—Selected.

The Chemistry of Girls
Definition: Girls are a polymeric, allotropic class of substance.
History : The first girl was discovered in a garden under a leaf, the same
year apples were discovered. Like the man who first made arsine, the discoverer
forfeited his life.
OccuiiiiENCE: Free, and in combination with men.
Physical Properties: Like crystals, girls may be distinguished from one
another by their color, odor, density and form. They have the power of changing
their form and color. Once or twice in a life-time you run across one altogether
different from all the rest, though observers do not seem always to be able to see
the great difference you observe so easily.
Chemical Properties:
"Sugar and spice.
And everything nice;
That's what little girls are made of."
The foregoing is not chemically true. Neither is it true that they are made
up (though many are), made up, I say, altogether of dust. On the contrary,
water forms seventy-five per cent, of their composition. Just think of it! Seven¬
ty-five per cent, water, plus dust, equals girls! Can it be that these lovely crea¬
tures, with the funny hats and the high-heeled oxfords, are, after all, only so many
solidified puddles, so to speak, as it were? Perish the thought.
Truly there is more to girls than just water and dust. After years of study
and experiment, I have succeeded in isolating the following elements, which are
quite constant in their occurrence in these wonderful bodies: Laughs, cries, smiles,
frowns, loves, hates, dates, kisses, deceit and sweetness.
I cannot give the technique employed to reveal all the foregoing elements.
However, I will take the time and give in detail the procedure for obtaining
kisses.
Experiment : The partial absence of light is desirable. Choose a girl whose
nose turns up. This is important; you do not want a nose in your way just at the
critical moment. Place said girl on a divan and get thereon yourself. Apply hot
air. Snuggle. And kisses will begin to ooze to her lips, from where they may be
easily removed.
The author does not claim that the foregoing is the only method of obtaining
kisses; not at all. There are many others. The one just described, however, is
the one most efficient. In case of failure to obtain kisses it is invariably due either
zm
gral€>l8S3q[
Ja
to awkwardness on the part of the operator—that is, faulty technique, or employ¬
ment of the wrong method Eor the particular case in band. For, remember, kisses
are constant in their appearance as a part of girls.
Girls have a great atlinity for new bonnets, jabots, talcum, and rosaline, and
will combine in any proportion with bonbons and soda water.
Girls' reaction to criticism is accompanied by a great deal of effervescent fum¬
ing, spiteful explosions and a marked elevation in temperature.
Fses : Fsed very largely in making trouble.
Conclusions: But do we care a slate pencil about the chemistry of girls?
Xaw! It's the girls we care about.
One touch of Winter makes the whole world sneeze.
J. R. Tucker.
