The Abused Art of Eating
i
(Note: The author has had so many requests for information as to the proper man
ner of eating the various courses of a dinner that he feels that there is a crying need for
general information on this subject. As there is apparently such an immediate need of this
information, only a few of the more important courses of a dinner have been touched upon
to hasten the publication to a waiting public. Some important things have been omitted, but
a careful perusal of the treatise will enable the diner to consume an ordinary repast with
credit to himself and his host. The author will endeavor to answer specifically any inquiries
as to dishes not touched on herein.)
POSITION, ETC., AT THE TABLE
First, in this connection, should be mentioned the feet. This may seem foreign
to the subject, but it must be remembered that your fellow guests at a dinner are
very much interested in the location of your feet. The old-fashioned idea that
they should be on the floor has been exploded, as they should, in reality, be most
anywhere but there. The most popular place at present seems to be on the feet of
your neighbor, provided you are a gentleman and your neighbors are ladies, and
that 3-our neighbors are wearing white shoes and stockings. This should be ascer¬
tained immediately upon sitting down by crawling under the table. If, upon thor¬
ough examination, it is found impossible to use your immediate neighbors as repos¬
itories for the feet, an effort should be made to place them in the lap of the party
immediately opposite to you. LTnfortunately some people are prohibited by nature
from doing this, in which event, and as a last resort, the feet should be wound
carefully around the legs of your chair where the butler will be sure to stumble
over them.
Next in importance is the napkin. The use of this article is steadily growing
in popularity. In fact, it is now being almost generally used, but the author has
observed that many people do not seem to realize exactly what it is for.
Some simply spread it across the knees, but this is a gross breach of form.
The proper place for it, on a. male guest, is around the edge of the collar, provided,
of course, the guest is wearing a collar. If not, it should be tucked into the arm-
holes of the vest. In case the guest is not wearing a vest; which of course he
should at a formal affair, the napkin should be tied around the neck, the ends
gracefully draped over the chest. It will be found that used in this way, it will
serve as an excellent receptacle for the soup which escapes in the function that
follows.
One of the most important reasons for the napkin being placed around the neck
is to prevent the guests from using it to wipe the perspiration from the forehead
and behind the ears. In good society, this is not being done at present.
GRAPE FRUIT
A great many dinners are being started with this fruit at present, and as the
average diner has great difficulty in handling it, a few words on the subject will
probablv not be out of place. Most hosts and hostesses are now furnishing a little
instrument known as a grape fruit compass to each guest. The fruit should then
be placed firmly on the floor, the diner kneeling with one knee on each side of it.
zm
]jral9l8i3!g[
and the little instrument inserted directly in the center of it. It requires some
practice to properly manipulate it, and the idea is to see in which direction the
juice is going to squirt.
After ascertaining this by the use of the compass it is removed, and the fruit
is then pressed on both sides with both knees at exactly the same time, the mouth
having been placed at the proper angle indicated by the compass. If properly
gauged, it will be found that the juice will land fairly in the waiting mouth, hut
unless the instrument is a perfect one and the directions are fully followed, it may
result in a shot in the eye or in the ear.
It would be advisable to try this first in the privacy of the bathroom, as there
arc some very powerful grape fruits being served these days, and some have been
known to shoot over several tallies, and it must be admitted that it would be quite
embarrasing to have such a thing happen in public, as well as being a waste of good
grape fruit.
SOUP
Volumes could be written on this subject, no two people apparently agreeing
nn its proper consumption, as is evidenced by the weird and unearthly sounds eman¬
ating from a group of diners. The author is firmly convinced, after giving the mat¬
ter careful study, that the spoon should he entirely eliminated, unless there is a
brass band or at least a full orchestra playing, as a few musicians cannot hope to
compete with a table of diners eating soup. Taking these facts into consideration
a small sponge should be furnished each guest, as it does its work noiselessly and in
addition avoids waste. Every drop can be consumed by the use of a sponge, and it
also does away with the necessity of tipping the plate to get the last of its contents,
thus avoiding the possibility of its skidding into the lap.
Too many cocktails should not be taken before a dinner where soup is to be
served in this manner, as a steady hand is required if the sponge is to be used in a
refined manner. If not carefully and properly handled its use is not recommended,
as otherwise it might prove a messy operation.
This method also prohibits the guest from breaking up crackers in his soup, as
the sponge will not absorb the crackers. That alone should insure its universal
adoption, regardless of its advantages as a silencer.
FISH OR ENTREE
It should not be necessary to go much into detail regarding this course, as it
is hard to go far wrong. Suffice it to say that if fish is served, fingers should not be
used except as a last resort. The use of the spoon should also be avoided, and the
knife should be used almost exclusively. If by any chance, however, the knife fails
to remove a bone and it should become lodged in the larynx of the diner, it is per¬
missible to use the fingers to dislodge it, provided a large, stout tooth-pick fails to
serve the purpose. The tooth-pick should be tried first in all cases.
There are no special rules applicable to the eating of foods coming under the
general heading of entrees. .Much depends upon the character of the food, and
there are too many varieties to go into a detailed explanation of each. It is sug-
gested that the reader watch his neighbor, and then do something entirely different.
If you are rich, you will very likely gain a reputation for originality, and for being
eccentric, and will be much sought after by the smart set.
If you are poor, you may be called vulgar. The prohibitive price of this book,
however, will prevent it from falling into the hands of the latter class, so my
readers may have no hesitancy in following the above formula.
ROASTS
At all swagger affairs where roast goose is served, the guests are furnished with
rubber coats, and in addition, the guests immediately to the right and left of the
carver with armor plate, as the impact of a fat goose flying off a platfer while in
the process of carving and coming into contact with a guest, is terriffie.
This rule does not apply to Jewish affairs, however, as they have, by long
experience, reduced the eating of a goose to a science.
There are no special rules applicable to the eating of other roasts, except to
sound the warning not to sop the bread in the gravy.
The author will not make a separate chapter of vegetables, as they are usually
served with the roast. The spoon should be used wherever possible, avoiding the
use of the knife, except where peas are served. There are special square-cornered
peas now being grown, as it was found very difficult to keep the ordinary pea from
rolling off the knife. Where the old-fashioned garden variety is served, though, it
will be found very convenient to mix them with the mashed potatoes. There is no
more pitiful or harrowing sight than to see some famished diner securing about one
pea in ten in the place they started for, and this can be avoided by the observance
of the above rule.
General, ordinary horse-sense should govern in the eating of other vegetables
not specifically mentioned here. This, however, should not be interpreted as mean¬
ing stable manners.
SALADS
Everything should be removed from the table, except the spoon, when the salad
is served. Fingers are used exclusively now, and the spoon is resorted to only to
get what dressing fails to stick to the salad when eaten. Formerly it was proper
to eat lettuce with a fork, but people became too exasperated chasing a piece of
lettuce from one side of the plate to the other, trying to get a foothold, so to speak,
that its use has been entirely abandoned, and the better classes have gone back to
Nature's own tools.
DESSERTS
The author regrets to say that he is not qualified to give extensive advice on
this subject, as he, in common with many others, has largely given up the use of
them for reasons that it is not necessary to go into detail. As far as he knows, they
are still being eaten by less enlightened ones in the same old way. If this were a
treatise on the human anatomy instead of on etiquette, he could advance good rea¬
sons why their use should be entirely abandoned.
COFFEE AND LIQUEURS
One demi-tasse and not to exceed ten liqueurs are being taken by the best peo¬
ple at the conclusion of a dinner. Any more than ten of the latter is very liable to
put the consumer in a condition that would entirely undo the good impression made
by a strict adherence to the rules of etiquette governing the previous courses.
Under no circumstances should the guest, when coffee in demi-tasses is served,
ask the hostess for a large cup with hot milk. This is permissible at breakfast, but
not at a formal dinner.
GENERAL INFORMATION
When cigarettes are furnished at the conclusion of a dinner, guests should use
ash receivers for their butts and ashes, and not the table cloth or coffee cups.
Neither should they strike matches on the furniture. The seat of the trousers is
the proper place.
Finger bowls are now taboo, for the reason that some diners seemed to often
mistake them for drinking utensils, and others insisted on trying to take a bath
in public.
Tooth picks have also almost entirely been done away with, as it was found
that diners abused this privilege. It is a hardship for the innocent to have to
suffer with the guilty, but until the latter class can be taught to wield the tooth
pick in a graceful manner, this useful article will have to be relegated to oblivion.
If it be found absolutely necessary to use it, the operation should be performed in
the cellar.
Last, but not least, it should be said that wdien the liqueurs and cigarettes are
served, guests should not so far forget themselves in their enjoyment as to put their
feet on the table. If this be done, however, the host or hostess should be given the
opportunity of removing the cloth and covering the table with pads to protect it
from the heels of the diners.
A writer of a letter to the editor wants to know "the proper way in which to
use a knife and fork in eating a meal."
The knife and fork should always be held in the hands, never with the toes.
W. N. A.

The Professional Ideal of the Dental Surgeon
(Having many times read and re-read the Oath and the Law of Hippocrates, that noble
and celebrated Greek physician of twenty-three centuries ago, I attempt here to scan a few
lines along this line of thought and principle, thinking it good for those who are about to
enter the Profession.)
MEDICINE is of all the arts the most noble; of its many branches the art
of dental surgery stands in the foreground in rank and file with general
medicine and surgery. But this is only recently so. In the past, owing
to the ignorance and narrow training of those who practiced it, and of those who,
inconsiderately, form a judgment of them, it wras far behind all the other arts. The
art is no longer one solely of mechanics, plugging in fillings and the like, but a
high and noble art, dealing with vital tissues and general health of mankind, de¬
manding of those who practice it a thorough practical knowledge and understand¬
ing of the anatomy and pathology thereof.
Now that dental surgery is, and righteously so, on a high and unimpeachable
plane, may those who practice it be competent and respectful men and ever diligent
and faithful of the noble art they are practicing.
"Inexperience is a bad treasure, and a bad fund to those who possess it,
wdiether in opinion or reality, being devoid of self-reliance and contentedness, and
the nurse both of timidity and audacity. For timidity betrays a want of powers,
and audacity a lack of skill. They are, indeed, two things, knowledge and opin¬
ion, of which the one makes its possessor really to know, and the other to be ignor¬
ant." Thus said Hoppocrates.
Be conscientious and thorough in all your work. Follow that system of regimen
which, according to your ability and judgment, you consider for the benefit of your
patients, and abstain from whatever is deleterious and mischievous.
With purity and holiness pass your life and practice your art.
While you faithfully continue to keep and practice these principles, may it be
granted to you to enjoy life and the practice of the art, respected and esteemed by
all men, in all times; but should you be not faithful in this respect, may the reverse
be your lot.
"Life is short, and the art long; the occasion fleeting; experience fallacious,
and judgment difficult."
The dental surgeon must not only be prepared to do what is right himself, but
also to make the patient, and the attendants co-operate.
Henry M. Needham.

ANOMALIES IN COLLEGE
Baldwin with his singing.
Turner with his eyes.
Armona with his temperature.
Wesley with his hair cut.
Callahan with his devotion.
Crank with his abnormal frenum labium.
Miss Robinson with her smile.
H. L. Parks with his mouth.
Mann with his wiggle.

Freshman asked: "What right have you to be wearing those things?"
"By heck! because I am a Senior," he answered.

Douglas: "Dying death of the pulp."

Busbee was in a fashionable Atlanta restaurant and pointing to a line on the
menu card, said to the waiter: "I'll have some of that, please."
"I'm sorry, sir," the waiter answered, "but the band is playing that."
It has recently been learned why Phillips came all the way from West Texas
to Atlanta, viz: he is learning to operate a moving picture machine.
A dentist's life is a paradox,
He may have money and lands and stocks,
His purse be flooded or suffer a drouth,
Still his business is always, "down in the mouth."
Let the ranks of other professions be full,
But the dentist somehow has a '' pull,''
And yet no matter how much he may brag,
He often—quite often runs up on a " snag.''
He is stocked with platinum, silver, and gold;
Even diamonds to him are often sold.
But seek where you will in North or South,
His life is always from "hand to mouth."
His credit may be good, his honor sound,
But his work to be " false'' is often found.
So he goes through life with its valleys and hills,
Till a hole in the ground (his last cavity) he fills.
—Selected.

A View of College Life
We 've learned our lessons well,
We 've cut up stiffs,
And breathed long whiffs,
Of that infernal smell.
We 've studied dead men 's bones,
And heard the live men 's groans,
We 've worked hard at night,
To learn our stuff just right.
Soon Spring will bring exams,
With all their days and nights of crams,
We worry and sweat, and fume and fret,
To get them off our hands.
When Summer comes at last,
And D.D.S. 's we are classed,
We give a cheer that all may hear,
Our College life is passed.
II. W. C.
